title: Fitch Affirms IMB Ltd at 'BBB+'; Outlook Stable
text:
Fitch Affirms IMB Ltd at 'BBB+'; Outlook Stable

(The following statement was released by the rating agency) Fitch Ratings-Sydney-October 13: Fitch Ratings has today affirmed the Long-Term Issuer Default Rating (IDR) of IMB Ltd (IMB) at 'BBB+'. The Outlook is Stable. IMB's other ratings were also affirmed at the same time. IMB Ltd; Long Term Issuer Default Rating; Affirmed; BBB+; RO:Sta ; Short Term Issuer Default Rating; Affirmed; F2 ; Viability Rating; Affirmed; bbb+ ; Support Rating; Affirmed; 5 ; Support Rating Floor; Affirmed; NF Key Rating Drivers IDRs AND VIABILITY RATING IMB's IDRs and Viability Rating are driven by its risk appetite and underwriting standards, which Fitch believes will remain generally in line with industry practice and peers. This should also underpin its asset quality through the cycle. IMB's lending standards are generally in line with other small Australian banks and remain tighter than three years ago, driven partly by increased regulatory oversight. Control frameworks have been strengthened to improve management of reputational and conduct risks, an area which has seen increased scrutiny in the sector. IMB has a stable business model and benefits from its regional focus, which allows the bank to have a stronger brand presence in its local market. However, the small franchise acts as a drag on its rating, and is unlikely to improve significantly in the short-to medium-term despite ongoing merger activity. The bank is a 'price-taker' in its core market of residential mortgages, which is dominated by the four major banks. Fitch expects IMB's asset quality to remain strong over the next two years, supported by the low-interest-rate environment and its underwriting standards. The low level of impaired loans should continue to compare favourably with international peers. Arrears increased slightly over financial year 2019 (FY19, to month/year), but remained at very low levels and are manageable by the bank. A sharp rise in unemployment remains the key downside risk, but this is not Fitch's base case. Fitch believes profitability will remain broadly consistent in FY20. Earnings and profitability growth will be challenged by margin pressure from competition, ongoing investments in digital capabilities, and rising regulatory costs. Fitch also expects the pending merger with Hunter United will increase expenses in the short term during the integration process. IMB's capital levels are in line with its small bank domestic peer group, and the bank maintains a comfortable buffer above the regulatory requirement. The declining CET1 ratio over the last four years reflects the bank's share-buyback activity. We expect IMB's capital ratios to stabilise in FY20, given the bank's growth plans and a more challenging earnings environment. SUPPORT RATINGS AND SUPPORT RATING FLOORS IMB's Support Ratings and Support Rating Floors reflect Fitch's view that while support from the authorities is possible, it cannot be relied upon due to the banks' small market shares and low systemic importance. RATING SENSITIVITIES IDR AND VIABILITY RATING IMB's Viability Rating and IDRs are sensitive to any increase in its risk appetite which may be evident from more aggressive underwriting standards or looser risk controls, possibly in an effort to improve the franchise. This may manifest in a larger-than-peer deterioration in asset quality, profitability and capitalisation in a downturn. The bank's funding profile could also be pressured by strong asset growth, which could in turn pressure ratings if not offset through adequate capital and liquidity management. Positive rating action is unlikely, given IMB's modest franchise. SUPPORT RATINGS AND SUPPORT RATING FLOORS IMB's Support Ratings and Support Rating Floors are sensitive to changes in Fitch's assumptions about the propensity or ability of the Australian sovereign (AAA/Stable) to provide timely support. ESG Considerations Unless otherwise disclosed in this section, the highest level of ESG credit relevance is a score of 3 - ESG issues are credit neutral or have only a minimal credit impact on the entity, either due to their nature or the way in which they are being managed by the entity.
